text:
Gentle Love,
Draw forth thy wounding dart,
Thou canst not pierce her heart;
For I, that do approve
By sighs and tears more hot than are thy shafts
Did tempt while she for triumph laughs. https://t.co/6hADMfj3ou

Out alas,
My faith is ever true,
Yet will she never rue
Nor yield me any grace;
Her eyes of fire, her heart of flint is made,
Whom tears nor truth may once invade. https://t.co/ATzwK3yWY4

All the night
My sleeps are full of dreams,
My eyes are full of streams.
My heart takes no delight
To see the fruits and joys that some do find
And mark the storms are me assign'd.

All the day
The sun that lends me shine
By frowns do cause me pine
And feeds me with delay;
Her smiles, my springs that makes my joys to grow,
Her frowns the Winters of my woe. https://t.co/sfI4a3lh8h

Come again!
That I may cease to mourn
Through thy unkind disdain;
For now left and forlorn
I sit, I sigh, I weep, I faint, I die
In deadly pain and endless misery. https://t.co/0Jx06MASO4

On love ðŸ§µ as sung about at the Danish Court in the 1610s 

Come again!
Sweet love doth now invite
Thy graces that refrain
To do me due delight,
To see, to hear, to touch, to kiss, to die,
With thee again in sweetest sympathy.

https://t.co/4OTuBaFVGe

@Gereon11765068 I don't think that's correct, Niedersachsen, the province with prop. the highest % ethnic Germans, have the highest fertility rate, 1.61, while Berlin and Hamburg (granted, they are urban) with a much, much lower % of Germans, have one of the lowest rates, 1.38 and 1.4

@Gereon11765068 How so? Soviet Communism, was rather conservative during most of the 20th centuries, jailing homosexuals and supporting father-mother families, how did they manage to raise a generation of Polish feminists in a country where the large majority support a ban on abortion?

@Agathon_B @TeDeum46060503 The Greek literally reads "but I say to the unmarried and the widows, good it is if they remain as I also am" 

"what I also am" isn't explicitly said. By reference to other facts it cannot be the state of unmarriedness, so it must be temporary abstinence for the service of God https://t.co/e00ZT4Wszt

@Agathon_B @TeDeum46060503 In v8 he says "it is best to remain as I" he does not say "remain unmarried" so what does the "remain as I" refer to? 

Well Paul was contingent when traveling around on his missions trips for the kingdom of God, which he hoped many others would follow him in.

@TeDeum46060503 @IustusEt @caleb11klein unable to establish doctrine unless we can also firmly embed that in the proto canon.

@TeDeum46060503 @IustusEt @caleb11klein The LXX is not a canon, so whether or not one receives or reject the LXX then that does not have a bearing on one's view of the canon. One can take either position. I personally view the deut. as inspired, but on account of their partial reception by the church view them as 1/

@account_plain Right. That's fair. I would though place the deut. akin to the antileg. of the NT though I also dislike the tendency some have to view the NT antileg too lowly. I mean who can doubt the divinity of Hebrews or 2nd John?

@account_plain Oh, interesting though. Gerhard and Chemnitz talks about the deut. as the OT antileg. 

What would make you hesitant to place the deut. as equal to the NT antileg?
@account_plain Like, if we cut out around 50% of the Psalms, Ester, 1 and 2 Chronicles etc. we wouldn't loose anything not found somewhere else?

@account_plain Right. I don't think they bring anything "additional" in that sense, and obviously they contain no teaching or any doctrine not explicitly taught in the NT or the proto-canon. But doubt whether we should approach Scripture in a sort of minimalistic way. 1/

@account_plain Melanchthon calls the deut. for "Scripture" in our confessions. Wisd. of Solomon has one of the clearest and most beautiful prophecies about Christ (chap 2, have you read this?) 

This is just the classical Orthodox position of Lutheranism :)

@NatProt Yes, it was quite common among many theologians after the book of Concord was written. But I think there are some major issues with it.

Could you, if you want, lay out your view of receptionism in a tweet or two?

@IustusEt @caleb11klein only partial reception of them by the church then we can't, on account of their uncertainty, use them to establish doctrine. Yet that does in no mean result in us not being able to personally affirm them as inspired. It is only problematic if we wanted to bind others on that 2/2

@IustusEt @caleb11klein Because our epistemic approach is twofold. It is internal and external. External by the witness of the church and internal by the witness of the spirit. Luther, our confessions and our theologians call the deut. Scripture and have placed them within the canon. But given the 1/
@JohnCarpenter64 You must be be joking? Are you actually being serious?
@ETGalindoPazan You're being sarcastic, right?
@caleb11klein I'd say so, but on account of their partial acceptance then we can't be certain of that and thus can't equate them with the proto canon
@JohnCarpenter64 Yeah.. so that would be reading your own definition of OT into that. No Christian tradition would take any issue with the three fold division of Scripture
@stbrianjoseph @JohnCarpenter64 Have you read Vatican I? These pop popish arguments are so boring
@JohnCarpenter64 Jesus said nothing at all about the exact extent of the canon
@G00DP3RSON The comment about one's daughter and the arrows is... wild
@JohnCarpenter64 On a serious note, they must naturally be included in the Bible, as Luther himself did, even if one doubts their full canonicity

@JohnFisher2dot0 @TheOtherPaul2 But both of these two traditions have their source in the later masoretic text, both being much younger than the LXX?

@JohnFisher2dot0 @TheOtherPaul2 Regarding the textual variant. The Key of David is found in one LXX manuscript, Vaticanus, that is not a specific type, but just a single (though important) manuscript. 

This variant is not included in any modern editions of the LXX it finds almost zero support. https://t.co/2a9NRysObp

@AngelosIoannid2 @JohnFisher2dot0 Hmm, the appeal to historic and episcopal continuity. The appeal to the indefectibility of the visible church. The appeal to low c catholicity of many of the doctrines rejected by the Protestants. The visible cohesion of the church. There's a few more, but these are strong imo
@JohnFisher2dot0 I think that is a fair example of John Cassian applied the imagery of keys from Matt 16 to Peter. Though that doesn't bring any support to the typology from Isaiah?

@JohnFisher2dot0 Regarding 1) I don't think there is such a thing as binding  or loosing apart from the keys. Peter is told he will, future, receive the keys -to bind and loose- and when he later receives them, they are received by all the apostles. Peter gets nothing the others dont receive also

@JohnFisher2dot0 Granting that Isai includes reference to a key, which I deny, then notice how Peter and the apostles are promised the keys, plural, to bind and loose, while Christ alone is promised the key, singular, of David. I don't think we can confuse keys of the kingd. and "Key of David"
@Akemi180 @JonnyYounboi No Papist held my view either! ....

@kennhistoria @Agathon_B @TheOtherPaul2 No that's a good idea. I think we could at least send each other 2-3 questions or so, and do a little prep on those, and then use that as a spring board for an informal convo? :)

@JohnFisher2dot0 I almost never agree with Nemesh but he is spot on here. That argument is terrible I think, especially compared to the other arguments RC actually do make, many of which deserves to be taken very serious

@kennhistoria @Agathon_B @TheOtherPaul2 Yeah that's a good idea too. But I hope we can be able to ask each other questions too. I mean, it wont at all be a formal debate, I am thinking more about a nice conversation. Did you see the one I had with Erick Ybarra?

@ErmikaSawin Hm, maybe I am not coming across correct. You don't think there is a difference between a word in a language encompassing two different concepts and then one unjustifiably dividing one concept into multiple different ones?
@PoeticCiaran Which I am not. I support the usage of icons for didactic and visual purposes. But the debate cannot at all be boiled down to that. A lot of Saints whole heartedly rejected icons

@PoeticCiaran I wrote my bachelor thesis on John Damascene's defense of icons and the iconoclasm in Byzantium. How familiar are you with this debate? I think it is a lot more complicated than iconoclasts = Nestorians.

The Council of Elvira was not Nestorian yet condemned icons 1/

@kennhistoria @Agathon_B @TheOtherPaul2 That sounds great! We can do it either on our channel, a friend of yours or my own? What ever you prefer.

I don't mean to attack your faith per se, but only certain parts of it which I see as erroneous. By far most of what you confess is good and pious! But SS sounds good

@ErmikaSawin In English the word "you" can be either a singular direct pronoun or a plural second person pronoun. The word chair can be a piece of furniture or an academic position. That's how we gloss the terms... That has nothing to do with arbitrary theological distinctions.
@velikovec @Agathon_B Augustine was, without a single splinter of a hair's breath a Roman Catholic. To even make that claim is laughable

@matthewpao1 I believe in heavenly rewards. Scripture is quite plain about them. The difference is that we are never told how or what they are, or that they can be earned. Only that we will be rewarded. There's no relationship of exchange. No tit for tat. Only a gift to be hoped for!

@kennhistoria @Agathon_B @TheOtherPaul2 Maybe we should do a video conversation on this topic? Though we disagree I feel that you've always been honest and wanting to engage with the position. If you feel the same way we should maybe think about doing a small convo on this topic
